topic: AQA GCSE Chemistry - Reactivity of Metals

questions.prompt: Put these metals in order from MOST to LEAST reactive:

feedback.correct: Perfect! The reactivity series shows how easily metals lose electrons.
feedback.incorrect: Not quite. Remember: Potassium Please (K) → Sodium (Na) → Calcium (Ca) → Magnesium (Mg) → Aluminium (Al) → Carbon (C) → Zinc (Zn) → Iron (Fe) → Copper (Cu) → Silver (Ag) → Gold (Au).

revisionFacts: The reactivity series ranks metals by how easily they lose electrons to form positive ions.
Potassium is the most reactive common metal; gold is the least reactive.
Metals above carbon in the series must be extracted by electrolysis.

questions.prompt: What type of ions do metals form when they react?

feedback.correct: Yes! Metals lose electrons to form positive ions (cations).
feedback.incorrect: Think about what metals do with their outer electrons during reactions.

revisionFacts: Metals form positive ions by losing outer shell electrons.
More reactive metals lose electrons more easily.
This electron loss is called oxidation.

questions.prompt: More reactive metals lose electrons _______ easily.

feedback.correct: Exactly right! Reactivity is all about how easily a metal gives up electrons.
feedback.incorrect: Hint: More reactive means it's easier for the metal to react, so...

revisionFacts: Reactivity increases as you go down Group 1 because outer electrons are further from the nucleus.
Distance from nucleus makes electrons easier to lose.
This is why potassium is more reactive than lithium.

questions.prompt: A displacement reaction happens when a more ________ metal pushes out a less reactive metal from its compound.

feedback.correct: Spot on! The reactivity series predicts displacement reactions.
feedback.incorrect: Hint: Which type of metal 'wins' and takes the compound for itself?

revisionFacts: A more reactive metal displaces a less reactive metal from its compound.
Example: Zinc + copper sulfate → zinc sulfate + copper
No reaction occurs if the metal is less reactive than the one in the compound.

questions.prompt: Why can't we use carbon to extract metals that are above carbon in the reactivity series?
correctAnswers: they are more reactive than carbon

feedback.correct: Perfect! Carbon can't displace more reactive metals from their ores.
feedback.incorrect: Hint: Think about displacement - can a less reactive element displace a more reactive one?

revisionFacts: Carbon can only reduce metals less reactive than itself.
Metals more reactive than carbon must be extracted by electrolysis.
This includes potassium, sodium, calcium, magnesium, and aluminium.

questions.prompt: Which metals do NOT react with dilute acids? (Select all that apply)

feedback.correct: Brilliant! Metals below hydrogen in the reactivity series don't react with acids.
feedback.incorrect: Remember: only metals ABOVE hydrogen react with acids. Copper, silver, and gold are below hydrogen.

revisionFacts: Only metals above hydrogen in the reactivity series react with acids.
Copper, silver, and gold are below hydrogen - no reaction with dilute acids.
Magnesium and zinc react vigorously with dilute acids, producing hydrogen.

questions.prompt: When Group 1 metals react with water, they produce a metal hydroxide and which gas?

feedback.correct: Correct! Group 1 + water → metal hydroxide + hydrogen.
feedback.incorrect: Hint: Think about the gas you can test with a lit splint (squeaky pop).

revisionFacts: Group 1 metals react with water to produce metal hydroxide + hydrogen gas.
The solution formed is alkaline (metal hydroxide dissolves).
Reactivity increases down Group 1: lithium < sodium < potassium.

questions.prompt: Write the general word equation for a Group 1 metal reacting with water:

feedback.correct: Perfect word equation!
feedback.incorrect: Hint: Group 1 metal + water → metal ________ + hydrogen

revisionFacts: General equation: Metal + water → metal hydroxide + hydrogen
Example: 2Na + 2H₂O → 2NaOH + H₂
The metal hydroxide makes the solution alkaline (pH > 7).

questions.prompt: Write the balanced symbol equation for sodium reacting with water (use M for the metal):

feedback.correct: Excellent balancing!
feedback.incorrect: Remember to balance: you need 2 metal atoms, 2 water molecules to produce 2 MOH and 1 H₂.

revisionFacts: Balanced equation: 2M + 2H₂O → 2MOH + H₂
The '2' is needed because H₂O has 2 hydrogens, and we make H₂.
For sodium specifically: 2Na + 2H₂O → 2NaOH + H₂

questions.prompt: What observations are common when lithium, sodium, or potassium react with water? (Select all)

feedback.correct: Perfect observation skills!
feedback.incorrect: Think about: Does the metal float? Is gas produced? Does the reaction release energy?

revisionFacts: All Group 1 metals float (they're less dense than water).
Fizzing shows hydrogen gas being released.
The reaction is exothermic - releases heat energy.

questions.prompt: What unique observation do you see with lithium and water (compared to sodium/potassium)?
correctAnswers: it moves slowly on the surface

feedback.correct: Yes! Lithium is the least reactive of the three.
feedback.incorrect: Hint: Lithium is the LEAST reactive - how does it move on the water?

revisionFacts: Lithium moves slowly on the water surface and fizzes gently.
It's the least reactive Group 1 metal (of the first three).
The reaction is slower and less vigorous than sodium or potassium.

questions.prompt: What unique observation do you see with sodium and water?

feedback.correct: Exactly! The heat from the reaction melts the sodium.
feedback.incorrect: Hint: The exothermic reaction releases enough heat to melt sodium into a ____.

revisionFacts: Sodium melts into a ball due to the heat of the reaction.
It moves quickly on the water surface.
More reactive than lithium, less reactive than potassium.

questions.prompt: What unique observation do you see with potassium and water?
correctAnswers: it burns with a lilac flame

feedback.correct: Perfect! The hydrogen produced ignites, giving a lilac flame.
feedback.incorrect: Hint: The hydrogen catches fire - what colour flame does potassium produce?

revisionFacts: Potassium reacts so vigorously the hydrogen ignites.
The flame is lilac/purple (characteristic of potassium).
It's the most reactive of lithium, sodium, and potassium.

questions.prompt: Order these Group 1 metals from LEAST to MOST reactive:

feedback.correct: Spot on! Reactivity increases as you go DOWN Group 1.
feedback.incorrect: Remember: reactivity increases down the group. Lithium is at the top, potassium lower down.

revisionFacts: Group 1 reactivity increases down the group: Li < Na < K < Rb < Cs.
Outer electrons are further from nucleus down the group.
Easier to lose outer electron = more reactive.

questions.prompt: Why do Group 1 metals become more reactive going down the group?
options: Outer electron is further from nucleus
Outer electron is closer to nucleus
questions.correctAnswer: Outer electron is further from nucleus

feedback.correct: Excellent understanding of electron structure!
feedback.incorrect: Hint: Think about distance from the nucleus and how many electron shells there are.

revisionFacts: More electron shells = outer electron further from nucleus.
Weaker attraction between nucleus and outer electron.
Outer electron lost more easily = more reactive metal.

questions.prompt: Complete the word equation: Metal + acid →

rejectFeedback.salt + water: Not water! Acids and metals produce hydrogen gas, not water.

feedback.correct: Perfect! Metal + acid always gives salt + hydrogen.
feedback.incorrect: Hint: Metal + acid → salt + _________ gas

revisionFacts: Metal + acid → salt + hydrogen (not water!).
Only metals above hydrogen in reactivity series react with acids.
The salt name depends on the acid used.

questions.prompt: How do you test for hydrogen gas?

rejectFeedback.relights a glowing splint: That's the test for oxygen! Hydrogen gives a squeaky pop with a LIT splint.

feedback.correct: Exactly! Hydrogen burns with a distinctive squeaky pop.
feedback.incorrect: Hint: Put a LIT splint near the gas - what sound does it make?

revisionFacts: Hydrogen test: lit splint → squeaky pop.
Hydrogen is flammable and burns in air.
Don't confuse with oxygen test (relights glowing splint).

questions.prompt: What do you observe when hydrogen is produced in a metal + acid reaction?

feedback.correct: Yes! The fizzing/bubbles are hydrogen gas being released.
feedback.incorrect: Hint: What do you see around the metal as gas is produced?

revisionFacts: Fizzing/bubbles indicate gas (hydrogen) being released.
More reactive metals fizz more vigorously.
The reaction is exothermic (releases heat).

questions.prompt: In salt preparation, what do you add excess metal to?

feedback.correct: Correct! Excess metal ensures all acid is used up.
feedback.incorrect: Hint: You're trying to neutralize all the ____.

revisionFacts: Step 1: Add excess metal to acid until no more reacts.
Excess ensures all acid is neutralized.
You'll see fizzing stop when acid is used up.

questions.prompt: After the reaction, what do you do to remove excess metal?

feedback.correct: Perfect! Filtration removes solid unreacted metal.
feedback.incorrect: Hint: How do you separate a solid from a liquid?

revisionFacts: Step 2: Filter to remove excess unreacted metal.
The filtrate contains the dissolved salt.
The residue is the unreacted metal.

questions.prompt: To get solid salt crystals from the solution, what do you do?

feedback.correct: Exactly! Evaporation removes water, leaving salt crystals.
feedback.incorrect: Hint: How do you remove the water to leave solid crystals?

revisionFacts: Step 3: Evaporate water to crystallize the salt.
Heat gently or leave to evaporate slowly.
You can also use crystallization by cooling a saturated solution.

questions.prompt: How can you tell which metal is more reactive when comparing reactions with acid?

feedback.correct: Great! More reactive metals react faster and fizz more.
feedback.incorrect: Hint: What do you observe that tells you the reaction is faster?

revisionFacts: More reactive metals fizz faster and more vigorously.
You can measure reaction rate by volume of hydrogen produced per minute.
Temperature increase also indicates faster reaction.

questions.prompt: Write the word equation for: zinc + iron chloride →

rejectFeedback.iron chloride + zinc: That's what you started with! Displacement means the metals swap places.

feedback.correct: Perfect! Zinc displaces iron because it's more reactive.
feedback.incorrect: Hint: Zinc is MORE reactive than iron, so it takes the chloride.

revisionFacts: Zinc + iron chloride → zinc chloride + iron.
Zinc is more reactive, so displaces iron from the compound.
The more reactive metal 'steals' the non-metal.

questions.prompt: Write the balanced symbol equation for zinc displacing iron from iron chloride:

feedback.correct: Brilliant! That's already balanced as written.
feedback.incorrect: Hint: Zn + FeCl₂ → ZnCl₂ + Fe (it's already balanced!)

revisionFacts: Zn + FeCl₂ → ZnCl₂ + Fe
Already balanced: 1 Zn, 1 Fe, 2 Cl on each side.
Zinc goes from 0 to +2 oxidation state (loses 2 electrons).

questions.prompt: Write the ionic equation for calcium displacing magnesium from magnesium sulfate:

feedback.correct: Perfect ionic equation! You've removed the spectator ions.
feedback.incorrect: Hint: Show only the ions that change. Sulfate (SO₄²⁻) is a spectator.

revisionFacts: Ionic equation: Ca + Mg²⁺ → Ca²⁺ + Mg
Spectator ions (SO₄²⁻) are left out of ionic equations.
Shows the actual displacement more clearly.

questions.prompt: What is a spectator ion?
correctAnswers: an ion that doesn't change in a reaction

feedback.correct: Exactly! Spectator ions are present but don't participate.
feedback.incorrect: Hint: Think about ions that just 'watch' the reaction without changing.

revisionFacts: Spectator ions don't change during the reaction.
They appear unchanged on both sides of the equation.
We omit them in ionic equations to show the actual change.

questions.prompt: In metal extraction, reduction means the ore _______ oxygen.

feedback.correct: Yes! Reduction = loss of oxygen (in oxygen-transfer terms).
feedback.incorrect: Hint: OIL RIG helps with electrons, but for oxygen-transfer: reduction removes oxygen.

revisionFacts: Reduction (oxygen-transfer) = loss of oxygen from ore.
Reduction (electron-transfer) = gain of electrons.
Metal ores are reduced to extract the pure metal.

questions.prompt: Why is carbon used in reduction of metal ores?
options: It's more reactive than all metals
It's the only method that works

feedback.correct: Exactly! Carbon reduction is much cheaper than electrolysis.
feedback.incorrect: Hint: Think about cost - is heating with carbon cheap or expensive?

revisionFacts: Carbon reduction is cheaper than electrolysis.
Carbon removes oxygen from metal oxides.
Only works for metals less reactive than carbon.

questions.prompt: What is electrolysis?
correctAnswers: using electricity to split a compound

feedback.correct: Perfect definition!
feedback.incorrect: Hint: Electro = electricity, lysis = splitting.

revisionFacts: Electrolysis = splitting a compound using electricity.
Used to extract reactive metals (above carbon in series).
Requires molten or dissolved ionic compound.

questions.prompt: When is electrolysis used to extract metals?
options: For metals more reactive than carbon
For metals less reactive than carbon
questions.correctAnswer: For metals more reactive than carbon

feedback.correct: Spot on! Carbon can't reduce more reactive metals.
feedback.incorrect: Hint: Which metals can't be extracted using carbon?

revisionFacts: Electrolysis extracts metals MORE reactive than carbon.
Includes K, Na, Ca, Mg, Al.
Carbon reduction doesn't work for these metals.

questions.prompt: What is the main disadvantage of electrolysis for metal extraction?

feedback.correct: Yes! Electrolysis needs lots of electrical energy.
feedback.incorrect: Hint: Think about the energy costs.

revisionFacts: Electrolysis is expensive - needs continuous electricity.
This is why aluminium used to be very expensive.
Carbon reduction is much cheaper if it works.

questions.prompt: Why is cryolite added to aluminium oxide in aluminium extraction?
options: To make it dissolve in water

feedback.correct: Perfect! This saves energy and cost.
feedback.incorrect: Hint: Pure aluminium oxide melts at over 2000°C - how can we make this cheaper?

revisionFacts: Cryolite lowers aluminium oxide's melting point from 2050°C to about 950°C.
This saves huge amounts of energy and money.
The mixture is then electrolyzed.

questions.prompt: Match the electrode to what's produced during aluminium extraction:

feedback.correct: Excellent! Al³⁺ gains electrons at cathode; O²⁻ loses electrons at anode.
feedback.incorrect: Remember: cathode attracts positive Al³⁺ ions, anode attracts negative O²⁻ ions.

revisionFacts: Cathode (-): Al³⁺ + 3e⁻ → Al (reduction).
Anode (+): 2O²⁻ → O₂ + 4e⁻ (oxidation).
Molten aluminium sinks to bottom and is tapped off.

questions.prompt: Why must the carbon anode be regularly replaced in aluminium extraction?
options: It reacts with oxygen and burns away
It dissolves in the molten mixture
questions.correctAnswer: It reacts with oxygen and burns away

feedback.correct: Exactly! The oxygen produced reacts with the carbon anode.
feedback.incorrect: Hint: What happens when carbon (from the anode) meets oxygen (produced at the anode)?

revisionFacts: Carbon anode reacts with oxygen: C + O₂ → CO₂.
This gradually burns away the anode.
Replacement adds to the cost of aluminium production.

questions.prompt: Complete: Metal + oxygen →

feedback.correct: Correct! Combustion of metals produces oxides.
feedback.incorrect: Hint: When metals burn in oxygen, they form metal _____.

revisionFacts: Metal + oxygen → metal oxide (combustion).
Example: 2Mg + O₂ → 2MgO
This is an oxidation reaction (metal gains oxygen).

questions.prompt: In oxygen-transfer reactions, oxidation means _______ of oxygen.

feedback.correct: Yes! Oxidation (oxygen-transfer) = gain of oxygen.
feedback.incorrect: Hint: When something is oxidised, it combines with oxygen.

revisionFacts: Oxidation (oxygen-transfer) = gain of oxygen.
Example: 2Mg + O₂ → 2MgO (magnesium is oxidised).
Don't confuse with electron-transfer definition.

questions.prompt: In electron-transfer reactions, oxidation means _______ of electrons.

feedback.correct: Perfect! OIL: Oxidation Is Loss (of electrons).
feedback.incorrect: Hint: Remember OIL RIG - what does OIL stand for?

revisionFacts: Oxidation (electron-transfer) = loss of electrons.
OIL RIG: Oxidation Is Loss, Reduction Is Gain.
Example: Na → Na⁺ + e⁻ (sodium is oxidised).

questions.prompt: In electron-transfer reactions, reduction means _______ of electrons.

feedback.correct: Perfect! RIG: Reduction Is Gain (of electrons).
feedback.incorrect: Hint: Remember OIL RIG - what does RIG stand for?

revisionFacts: Reduction (electron-transfer) = gain of electrons.
OIL RIG: Oxidation Is Loss, Reduction Is Gain.
Example: Na⁺ + e⁻ → Na (sodium ion is reduced).

questions.prompt: Write the half-equation for sodium being oxidised:

feedback.correct: Excellent! Sodium loses 1 electron when oxidised.
feedback.incorrect: Hint: Oxidation = loss of electrons. Na loses 1 electron to form Na⁺.

revisionFacts: Half-equation: Na → Na⁺ + e⁻
Shows loss of 1 electron (oxidation).
Group 1 metals form +1 ions.

questions.prompt: What is a control variable in an experiment?

feedback.correct: Correct! Control variables ensure a fair test.
feedback.incorrect: Hint: What do you keep the SAME to make the test fair?

revisionFacts: Control variable = kept constant throughout the experiment.
Ensures only the independent variable affects the dependent variable.
Example: same volume of acid, same temperature, same surface area.
